awd_titl_txt: P2C2: Evaluating the Causes and Consequences of Extreme Holocene Paleo-Droughts in North America
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to understand the causes of persistent and severe drought in the continental United States (US) at particular periods in the past using climate model simulations and paleo records. Warming of the subtropical North Atlantic and local dust feedbacks have been shown to cause drought conditions in North America. 

The researchers hypothesize that during the Early to Mid-Holocene and in the Medieval Warm Period (MWP), these effects combined to create severe droughts that are far larger than observed during the modern historical period.  In the Early Holocene, North American proglacial lakes began to drain, leading to a pulse of freshwater into the North Atlantic around 8.2 ka. Enhanced dust emissions from the desiccated glacial lake beds are found in proxy records in the northcentral US, but the role of enhanced North American dust deposition on climate change has not been assessed. 

The researchers will explore the role of sea surface temperature perturbations and local and remote dust-climate feedbacks on extreme Holocene paleo-droughts in North America as well as the impact of drought and dust on ice sheet extent.

The project will support an early career female scientist to develop skills in model design and development, as well as enhance her participation in the NCAR paleoclimate modeling group. The researchers will participate in the University of Miami SEEDS (Scientists and Engineers Expanding Diversity and Success) program, which has career workshops, networking, and distinguished lectureships, and the annual Women in Science Day that brings middle school girls to campus to meet with female scientists to learn about their research and potential career paths. In addition, the project will entrain undergraduate students as part of their undergraduate student thesis.

por.por_cntn:
The term Atlantic Multidecadal Variability/Oscillation (AMV/AMO) is used to describe multidecadal SST variability in the North Atlantic Ocean that is evident in both observations and in proxy records. The AMV can influence rainfall around the basin as well as hurricane frequency. The drivers of the AMV are still being debated in the literature. Some studies point to the importance of internal dynamics arising in the atmosphere, ocean, or coupling between the two, while others point to external forcing arising from natural and anthropogenic factors, including volcanic eruptions and changes in the concentrations of greenhouse gases and pollutants. A better understanding of the underlying contributors to the AMV can lead to improved forecasts of societally important AMV impacts. In Klavans et al. (2022), Murphy et al. (2021), and Waite et al. (2020), we show that the importance of these internal and external drivers has evolved over the last millennium. In Klavans et al. (2022), we showed that prior to the Industrial Revolution, volcanic eruptions were the dominant forcing on the AMV. This was in agreement in Waite et al. (2020), which compared a new marine based AMV record from a 600-year-old Bahamian sclerosponge to climate model simulations. Since the mid-twentieth century, we show that external anthropogenic forcing is the primary driver of the AMV (Murphy et al. 2021, Klavans et al., 2022) and plays a large role on AMV impacts such as summer rainfall over Florida (Klavans et al., 2020). This evolving role for forcing has implications on attribution of AMV driven rainfall anomalies over North America. The goal of this work was to better understand how the AMV influenced drought conditions over North America during the Early to Mid-Holocene. We focus on the subtropical branch of the AMV, which was shown to be responsible for generating rainfall anomalies over the surrounding continents. We used a simplified modeling framework to test the roles of the North Atlantic SSTs, orbital forcing, and dust feedbacks on North American hydroclimate. Our results show that orbital forcing in combination with both remote and local dust-climate feedbacks result in circulation changes that include a weaker North Atlantic subtropical high and stronger North Pacific subtropical high. These changes reduce precipitation over central and western North America. These results highlight the importance of dust-climate feedbacks on past megadrought conditions over North America. 

 

Our regular group meetings provided an opportunity for mentoring on both research and senior thesis writing for several undergraduate students. There have been a number of presentations where our results have been disseminated at scientific meetings but also in local outreach talks, such as the UM Butler Center for Service and Leadership and at the Climate Cafe Seminar Series for the Rosenstiel School for Marine, Atmospheric, and Earth Science. In addition, research tools, methods, and findings from this work have been used in undergraduate Meteorology and Environmental Science classes that were taught by both PIs.
